I would like to give you some slaves.
Appreciated. We will find a place for them here.

The time of clash of cultures and gods.
The time of great leaders and legendary battles.
The time of change...

Forge your destiny in a world where your greatest weapon 
is not just the sword at your side, 
but the wit, courage, and determination you carry within.

Welcome to Eastern Europe 1259, traveler. 
Your legend begins now.
The owner of this castle does not allow you to recruit troops here.
You can't recruit in the enemy's castle.

The Balts, who live along the southeastern Baltic Sea, have their own languages, unique cultural practices, and pagan beliefs. They organize themselves into tribes, each led by a chieftain, maintaining independence while sharing a common cultural and religious bond.
Northern Crusaders embarked on military campaigns to Christianize the Baltic peoples, leading to significant cultural and territorial changes in the region.

Rus' culture, notable in Eastern Europe, blends Slavic traditions with influences from neighboring regions. It encompasses city-states like Kiev, Novgorod, and Vladimir, each governed by a prince. The society is hierarchically structured with princes, nobles, free peasants, and servants. Predominantly Eastern Orthodox since Prince Vladimir's Christianization in 988, Rus' culture aligns closely with Byzantium, contrasting with Western Catholic and Baltic pagan customs.

Finno-Ugric Old-Estonian culture is a robust, forest-dwelling society with a deep reverence for nature, practicing ancient animistic rituals and speaking a unique Finno-Ugric language, expert in guerrilla warfare and skilled in crafting from natural materials, reflecting their symbiotic relationship with the dense woodlands of northeastern Europe.

I am balt. But for 20 years, I fought for the teutons. Indeed, most balts my age learned their trade in the army. We saw no dishonor in it. They fed us well, they paid us well, they respected our courage.

But my lord is gone - died in the battle. And since Mindaugas became king, well, he's gotten the young to think that to fight for the teutons is treason. Treason to what? 'Lithuania'? There is no Lithuania. Never has been. Just a bunch of quarreling chieftains, who'll steal your cows as soon as you turn your back on them.
Anyway, well, I've had it with narrow escapes from charging knights, and I'm going to seek work in a more professional force.

I am balt by birth but I served with the teutons. Many of us did. A brave lord, a captain who cares for his men... What does it matter in which language your oath of fealty is given, as long as you honor it?

I am the prince of horsethieves! I have stolen teuton mares from amid the tents and ridden them across the desert under the moon, I have taken rus stallions from their paddocks, the sturdy ponies of the polacks, and the steady geldings of the mongol lancers. But, I'll be the first to admit, it is risky work, so sometimes I do other jobs.

My family was not one of the greatest clans of the Prussians, but neither are we among the poorest. When I came of age, my family sent me to join the Wolfskins. You may have heard of this tradition - for three years we live in the woods and do not eat cooked meat, wear spun cloth, or sleep under a roof, and according to the law we are beasts, not bound by the laws of men.

Aye, once I made a fine living, in the Kievan Rus, stopping merchants on the roads and asking 'em for a bit of change. But there was a lass there, beautiful as the moon and just as cold, and she was my undoing. Courted by an local chieftain but I thought, I can do better than that, with my takings, and I brought her the pick of the rings and finery and asked her to pass the evening with me.

She agreed, eagerly enough! There was wine and talk, but too much wine, and I slept off. Then woke in the morning, I did, and hooves were clattering outside and up comes the chieftain and a file of horsemen, and away they took me to the town to be hanged.

My uncle - he had a great herd of cows, and in the Semogitian upcountry that is only kind of wealth we value. But they were taken by his chief herdsman, a man we trusted. So we took up spears to get them back, but my uncle was now poor, but the thief had many kinsmen. Having nothing else to lose, my uncle ordered that even the women of our family take up spears and ride out to fight, and so we did.

I'm an engineer. Most of us learned our trade and got our contacts through the army. It was a good system: it was the master's money, so the master's servants kept a close eye on us. But as everyone knows, the Grand Master ran out of money. The governors are in charge of fortifications now, and all they have to go on is the say-so of other engineers.
I'm an engineer, with an army training. I'm sure by now you've met a few of us around, and know a bit about what we can do.
See, there's a lot of tales about me, and only some of them are true. The rus call me by one name, the balts by another.
My father was a rider in the east. We had a small estate to pay for his horse and armor. I was raised to take his place on the rider's troop rosters when he came of age.

But the Mongols overran us, and he was slain, and our land was taken. Its revenues now belong to some tarkhan. Alas, the Kingdom has little land to grant today, even to trained cavalrymen like myself who wish to serve. And horses are expensive.

You may call it pride, but I do not wish to enlist as a foot soldier. So I work here in town, for merchants, for pay, a hired sword. All I can say is that I hope one day to purchase the land I need to serve our master, whoever sits in the throne, as my father did.
A cavalier of the kingdom doing errands for traders! The shame of it!
I'm a former rider. Our skills, and our honor, needs no further introduction. But I was unable to afford my horse and armor, so I took work with merchants, as a hired sword.

I'm a soldier by trade. I've served in the army for 20 years. Once upon a time they were worthy of being called 'soldier.' We served together for years, and we'd die rather than see our standards falter or fall.
But our general led us into an ambush. You may have heard that story. I was laid up sick at the time. But a lot of my comrades didn't come back, and things were never the same afterward.

After so-called reforms, they try to maintain an army on the cheap, letting the rich run the show out of their own pocket. No wonder the whole thing's collapsed into a bunch of squabbling factions and we're mocked by the barbarians we used to rule.

I'm a soldier. How we came to this sorry state is a sad tale that you've no doubt heard already from my comrades. But I'm sure you're familiar with our mettle in battle, and our skill at turning youths into soldiers.

You may have heard of Ladimos the Red. He preached that the Heavens were getting ready to unload their wrath on landowners and merchant, that we had to drive them out and live pure lives and we'd be rewarded with a Pure Ruler, come down from the skies. This was some 10 years ago. Well, a lot of us ran off to follow him, some of us believed him and some of us had debts and some just wanted to take a lick at those that oppressed us.

We built a great temple in the back country, out in the bush, called it the Kingdom of Truth. We whipped two detachments sent to track us down. But Ladimos died, 'Called up to Heaven' he said on his deathbed, and then we lost our way a bit. We needed food and we needed money, so our chiefs started collecting 'taxes' from the villages below. Some started taking money from lords and merchants for protection of caravans. And those who grumbled - well, they started turning up dead in the dry streambeds.

My family had debts, so I signed up to be a soldier. I guess I always liked men's work more than women's work. The army took hill women as scouts but I was never the hidey-sneaky type. So I did what I did to be in the spear line.
I dressed as a man to serve in the army. There are many of us who've done that, believe it or not. You've probably met one of us before, even if you didn't know it.

My father was a merchant in Berlin. We lived in a rich house, with many servants. I wanted for nothing. Our neighbor was a moneylender, who specialized in loans to the guard. That turned out to be a bad neighborhood in which to live, when the riots came.

Far back as I remember, I was living on the streets of Vienna with a bunch of other dirty, barefoot scrogs. A group of men in our alley, they called themselves the Centaurs, I guess they took a liking to me. Gave me special errands to run from them - started with picking pockets, ended with sticking knives into their enemies. Back then I'd do anything for a handful of figs and cheese and a pat on the head.
Then came the day that Vienna burned, and everyone was out looting and robbing, and that was my chance. Lifted a bag of silver from the Centaurs' stash and lit out on the road.

I was an orphan, you see. Worked for a gang, as our kind must so often do. Did their foul work for them. But they perished in a siege, and I decided to strike out on my own, see what this fine land could offer me.
I'm a surgeon. I trained at the academy in Prague. I had many rich and influential patients in the town. I thought I was well shielded from the intrigues and dangers of the world.

But one day I was contacted by an agent of the Bureau of Barbarian Affairs. I do not know how well you know them. At first they wanted small harmless details about my patients. To do so was a violation of my oath, but I was anxious to have the favor of the Bureau. But soon they began to call on me for more and more.

One time they came at midnight - they had a man who plotted against the King, they said, and they needed a confession, and wished me to use my art to elicit that confession. If I refused, they said, they would disclose our relationship to my patients - I would be ruined. I went with them, to my shame, and what I was asked to do to that man's body -- I shall not repeat it.

I was a surgeon, trained at the academy. But my home and infirmary were burned in a bout of unrest, and now I must wander the world a bit. There are many of us out there, you know, forced to make what living we can.

My father was a cavalry man. Alas, he died in battle against the Mongols, and I was placed under the local archon's guardianship. He had eyes for my father's estate, modest as it was, so he arranged for me to be married to his cousin.

I fled a bad marriage. There are many like me; I meet them in every tavern. I am lucky in that my father was a cavalry man, and taught me to ride and fight before he died, and I suppose that's how I must make a living.
I was an herbalist in a village in the north. But our home was raided, and I've been forced to wander in search of work. There are many like me on the roads of Kievan Rus.

Started in the Prince's guard. I found that I was the only real warrior among them. They were all about marching here and there in their pretty uniforms, not pulling sword from scabbard for months on end. I told them what I thought, and my captain told me to keep my mouth shut or leave. So I left.

Then I joined the gang. They spent most of their time hunkering behind their shields. Ha! Me, I'd wade into the midst of the enemy, dealing out death right and left - and, well, all they had to say afterward was 'Why didn't you keep ranks?'
Let me tell you friend, I'm hard. I've fought with the mercenaries worth their salt, I've been with them. Others may tell you've they've done what I've done, but I'm the real thing.
Aye - you've heard about the death of the last Prince?

I'll tell you - what most people believe is a pack of lies. I was in the Prince's guard. We took our discipline seriously; we were proud of it. Then the riots happened. What I saw in Kyiv.. Even now it makes me feel ashamed.
I have heard about the riots in Kyiv. It was an ugly thing all round.
The guard didn't kill the Prince? Funny, that's not what the witnesses said.

I was part of the old Prince's Guard. But the people turned on us after his death, and attacked us. Maybe you've heard the story before. There's a whole lot of us, spat out into the world by the ungrateful rus.

We rus have a tradition. If two people have a dispute, and there's no witnesses, so it all comes down to one man's word against another's, then we let them settle it with swords. If one man doesn't like to fight, he can hire someone else to do the fighting. That's how it works with us. Probably other people do the same, because it's a good tradition.

King Mindaugas of Lithuania is the revered first king of Lithuania, known for his strategic acumen and diplomatic skill in uniting the Lithuanian tribes under a single banner in 1253. As of 1259, he continues to strengthen his realm through both alliances and conquests, working towards the consolidation of his kingdom and the expansion of its influence across Eastern Europe.

Morta is Queen of Lithuania upon her husband King Mindaugas's accession. She is Mindaugas' second wife. He killed her first husband Vismantas from the Bulaičiai family in the power struggle in 1251. Morta is a capable woman who advises her husband in political affairs and is a fierce defender of Western Christianity.

The Kingdom of Lithuania exists from 1251. King Mindaugas is the first chieftain crowned as King of Lithuania with the Pope's assent. The formation of the Kingdom of Lithuania represents a partially successful attempt at unifying all surrounding Baltic tribes into a single state.

The Teutonic Order is a Catholic religious institution founded as a military society in 1190 in Acre, Kingdom of Jerusalem. It is the leading power of The Northern Crusades or Baltic Crusades - colonization and Christianization campaigns undertaken by Catholic Christian military orders and kingdoms, primarily against the pagan Baltic, Finnic and West Slavic peoples around the southern and eastern shores of the Baltic Sea, and also against Orthodox Christian Slavs.

Prussia is a loose alliance of pagan Prussian tribes with similar languages and cultures. Prussian tribes are organized in a loose confederation led by local chieftains. Their society is largely tribal and clan-based, with leaders known as 'kriwe' or 'kriwes' who hold both religious and political authority. These leaders are supported by a council of nobles or elders. The Prussian tribes do not have a centralized state structure, and their political organization are more focused on local governance and tribal coalitions, which often shifted alliances and rivalries.
Baltic Tribes is a loose alliance of pagan baltic tribes with similar languages and cultures.

Rus' culture, notable in Eastern Europe, blends Slavic traditions with influences from neighboring regions. It encompasses city-states like Kiev, Novgorod, and Vladimir, each governed by a prince. The society is hierarchically structured with princes, nobles, free peasants, and servants. Predominantly Eastern Orthodox since Prince Vladimir's Christianization in 988, Rus' culture aligns closely with Byzantium, contrasting with Western Catholic and Baltic pagan customs.

The Balts, who live along the southeastern Baltic Sea, have their own languages, unique cultural practices, and pagan beliefs. They organize themselves into tribes, each led by a chieftain, maintaining independence while sharing a common cultural and religious bond.
The Northern Crusaders are a group of Teutonic Knights who embarked on military campaigns to Christianize the Baltic people, leading to significant cultural and territorial changes in the region.

The Balts, who live along the southeastern Baltic Sea, have their own languages, unique cultural practices, and pagan beliefs. They organize themselves into tribes, each led by a chieftain, maintaining independence while sharing a common cultural and religious bond.

The Chronicle of Henry of Livonia mentions the Selonians at the beginning of the 13th century, when they were conquered and christened. The author of the chronicle describes the Selonians as Lithuanian allies. Their lands were subjects of the principalities of Jersika and Koknese, which were vassals of the principality of Polotsk. The Southern lands however were ruled by Lithuanian lords.

The Latgalians are an Eastern Baltic tribe whose origin is little known. In the 5th and 6th centuries, they lived in the west of the Aiviekste River, and later on in nearly all the territory of that region. In the first two decades of the 13th century, the Western Latgalians allied with German (mainly Saxon) crusaders. Their lands (the Eldership of Tālava, the Principality of Jersika and the Principality of Koknese) were incorporated into Livonia as vassal states. In the 11th century, Eastern Orthodoxy started to spread in Latgalian lands from Polotsk and Pskov. In the 12th century, Latgalian lands and their rulers paid tribute to the dukes of Polotsk. During the Livonian crusade in the 13th century, Latgalian elders switched from Eastern Orthodoxy to Roman Catholicism and became vassals of the Livonian Order.

The Livonians referred to themselves as rāndalist - 'coast dwellers' and supported themselves mainly by fishing, but also by agriculture and animal husbandry. Since they controlled an important trade route, the Daugava River, their culture was highly developed through trade with the Gotlanders, Rus and Finns, and, from the end of the first millennium AD onwards, with the Germans, Swedes and Danes. During the Livonian Crusade, once prosperous Livonia was devastated, and whole regions were almost completely depopulated. This vacuum was filled by Curonians, Semigallians, Latgallians and Selonians – who started to move into the area around 1220, and continued to do so for at least thirty years.

On the eve of Northern Crusades, the people then residing in Saaremaa(Ösel) were described in the Livonian Rhymed Chronicle: The Oeselians, neighbors to the Kurs (Curonians), are surrounded by the sea and never fear strong armies as their strength is in their ships. In summers when they can travel across the sea they oppress the surrounding lands by raiding both Christians and pagans
